Hi Mike,

rognorak wrote:

>
>2.  I looked at the experiments that come bundled with SharpNeat, and 
>I see I have to define a function that returns fitness in Network 
>Evaluator Function to do my own experiment.  How do I set a fitness 
>threshold to the program, so that SharpNeatGui will know to stop when 
>it has found a network of sufficient performance? 
>
>  
>

Currently there is no setting to do this so you would have to modify the 
code. One way would be to add the fitness threshold as a property on 
IExperiment, this can then be checked from Form1.SearchThreadMethod() - 
when the current fitenss passes the threshold just set stopSearchSignal 
to true to stop, or just have a look at the code in there that 
terminates the search thread. You can also see code in there for saving 
the best genome - which is something you probably want to happen once 
the threshold is passed (or target acheived).


>3.  Can I setup SharpNeat to only evolve the topology of a network, 
>and determine the weights with traditional back prop ANN training?
>  
>

There are probably a few different ways of doing this. An easy way would 
be to set the connection weight mutation rate to 0.0 so that no CPU time 
is wasted searching weights. The evaluation function could then decode 
the genome to something other than one of the standard ANN classes which 
supports backprop (or just bolt backprop onto one of the existing 
classes). You can then run backprop on each ANN as part of the 
evaluation function.

In fact you could evolve the weights AND start the backprop from the 
weights in the genome, instead of randomly generating weights (or using 
one of the weight generting schemes for backprop).

Regards,

Colin
